title: Best Home Remedies for Itchy Skin & What to Avoid

steps.title: Wet a cloth and hold it against your skin for about 30 minutes.
steps.content: Wet a cloth and hold it against your skin for about 30 minutes. Use cold water to soothe your skin and stop the itching. Over time, the water will help soften and remove dead skin that might be causing irritation. [1] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source You can also press ice packs or frozen bags of peas or beans against the itchy area, but wrap them in a towel first. Apply frozen items for between 10-20 minutes about once a day. Stay away from heating pads or hot compresses, as that could make your skin more irritated.

steps.title: Soak in the shower for 10 to 15 minutes at a time.
steps.content: Soak in the shower for 10 to 15 minutes at a time. Hop into the shower and turn the water to cool (but not cold). Stay in there until your itching subsides. [2] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source You can also soak in a bath full of cool water, although that might be slightly less comfortable than taking a cool shower.

steps.title: Try soaking in it for 20 to 30 minutes to soothe your skin.
steps.content: Try soaking in it for 20 to 30 minutes to soothe your skin. Fill up your tub with cool to lukewarm water, then add in 2 cups (400 g) of unprocessed and uncooked oatmeal. Soak in the bath until your skin feels better or you get too cold. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source You can also make a paste out of uncooked oat flour and water to target specific areas of your skin. Simply apply it to your itchy skin and leave it on for 20 to 30 minutes for some relief.

steps.title: Apply moisturizer to damp skin to lock in hydration.
steps.content: Apply moisturizer to damp skin to lock in hydration. Dry skin is a big cause of itching. Purchase a fragrance-free moisturizer and apply it every day, focusing on the areas that are the itchiest. Try to put on your moisturizer right after you get out of the shower when your skin is the wettest. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Ingredients like alcohol and added fragrances can cause irritation and make your skin even drier. Thick ointments like petroleum jelly work well on severe skin irritation like eczema. Lotions and creams are best for normal to dry skin.

steps.title: These topical cooling agents can help soothe and relieve itching.
steps.content: These topical cooling agents can help soothe and relieve itching. Buy a lotion that contains calamine or menthol from your local drugstore, then smooth it onto your itchy skin. You can use these products daily to help reduce irritation and itching over time. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source These creams work almost instantly, and you’ll actually feel a cooling sensation on your skin.

steps.title: Aloe vera contains anti-bacterial and anti-inflammatory properties.
steps.content: Aloe vera contains anti-bacterial and anti-inflammatory properties. It also has plenty of vitamin E that is useful in the treatment of burns and helps to reduce inflammation and itching. Pick up some aloe vera gel from your local drugstore and smooth it onto your irritated skin. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Aloe vera gel from a store is fine, but fresh aloe vera is ideal! If you have a whole aloe plant, take a piece, cut it open, and then apply the gel over the itchy skin.

steps.title: Dry air can make your skin even itchier.
steps.content: Dry air can make your skin even itchier. If you live in a dry climate, set up a humidifier in your home to put moisture back into the air and keep your skin from drying out. This is especially important during the winter time when the heating in your home could be drying out the air. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Try to clean your humidifier regularly to avoid a buildup of mold or mildew. Check your instruction manual for an exact timeline of how often you should be cleaning it.

steps.title: Too many showers or baths can make your skin itchier.
steps.content: Too many showers or baths can make your skin itchier. When you shower, use lukewarm water instead of hot, and try not to stay in the shower for more than 10 to 15 minutes. When you get out, moisturize right away to avoid itchy skin. [8] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source Warm water can dry out your skin and make it itchier.

steps.title: Tight clothes can cause irritation.
steps.content: Tight clothes can cause irritation. Similarly, clothing made of wool and synthetic fabrics can cause itchiness, especially if you have sensitive skin. Try to pick out clothes made of cotton that are a little loose so they don’t irritate your skin. [9] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Cotton clothing also helps wick away moisture and sweat, which can help prevent itchy skin.

steps.title: Unfortunately, scratching usually makes itching worse.
steps.content: Unfortunately, scratching usually makes itching worse. If you’re really having trouble keeping your hands away from your itchy skin, try patting or tapping the skin instead of scratching with your nails. Keep your nails short so you aren't tempted to scratch and make your skin even more irritated. [10] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Scratching can also lead to infection if you accidentally break the skin.

steps.title: Regular detergent contains chemicals that may irritate your skin.
steps.content: Regular detergent contains chemicals that may irritate your skin. Try to find unscented detergent or detergent made specifically for sensitive skin. In addition, try putting all your clothes through an extra-rinse cycle to remove any lingering traces of the detergent. [11] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source You may also want to consider using all-natural or organic cleaning products that minimize added chemicals.

steps.title: Being tired can make your skin irritation worse.
steps.content: Being tired can make your skin irritation worse. In general, try to sleep for around 8 hours each night to stay rested and wake up refreshed. If you have trouble falling asleep, try turning off your electronics 30 minutes before you go to bed, and make sure your room is cool, dark, and quiet. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If your itchy skin is keeping you awake, use a cooling agent about 30 minutes before you go to sleep.

steps.title: Practice yoga, meditation, and self-care often.
steps.content: Practice yoga, meditation, and self-care often. The less stressed you are, the better your skin will feel. Try to do something relaxing for yourself every single day to lower your stress levels and stay happy. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Reducing stress can look different for everyone. Don’t be afraid to try out a few different relaxation methods before you find something you like!

steps.title: They can actually make itchy skin worse.
steps.content: They can actually make itchy skin worse. As you shop around for anti-itch products, you might find sprays like Benadryl or Caladryl. However, experts warn that products like these can cause irritation, and it’s hard to control the dosage in a spray. [14] X Research source
